children: Virus- or drug-induced acute hepatitis usually causes serum aminotransferase elevations >1000 U/L (ALT > AST) and serum total bilirubin levels >15 mg/dL.
ALT values >5000 U/L usually result from acetaminophen hepatotoxicity or hepatic ischemia.
An AST/ALT ratio >2.0 suggests alcoholic hepatitis.
and low serum albumin values imply severe hepatocellular dysfunction.
Minimal ALT and AST elevations in a patient with obesity, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension suggest nonalcoholic liver disease.
